comment: Seccomp profile for ClickHouse server in Docker. defaultAction blocks unlisted syscalls with ENOSYS (38).

syscalls.comment: File I/O basics — ClickHouse reads/writes data parts, logs, configs, and temporary files constantly
Random-offset file access — MergeTree reads columns at arbitrary offsets within data part files
Disk space preallocation — ClickHouse preallocates space for data parts and write-ahead logs to reduce fragmentation
Efficient data transfer — sendfile is used for HTTP responses and replication data transfer without user-space copies
File metadata and directory operations — ClickHouse inspects data part directories, checks file sizes, and manages symlinks for detached parts
Directory and file management — creating/removing data part directories, renaming parts during merges, hard-linking during mutations
File descriptor control — ClickHouse duplicates fds for child processes, sets close-on-exec, and manages non-blocking I/O
File locking — ClickHouse uses advisory locks to prevent concurrent access to data directories
Memory-mapped files — MergeTree engine mmaps index files and mark files for fast random access during queries
Heap allocation — ClickHouse uses jemalloc which calls brk/sbrk for small allocations and memory arena management
Networking — ClickHouse listens on TCP ports (native 9000, HTTP 8123, replication 9009) and connects to ZooKeeper/Keeper
Network data transfer — ClickHouse sends/receives query data, replication chunks, and distributed query results
Async I/O multiplexing — ClickHouse uses epoll for its network server (Poco library) to handle thousands of concurrent connections
Linux AIO — ClickHouse uses io_submit/io_getevents for async reads of MergeTree data parts to overlap I/O with computation
Event and timer file descriptors — ClickHouse uses eventfd for thread pool wakeups and timerfd for background task scheduling
Inotify — ClickHouse watches config files for live reload (config.xml, users.xml) without requiring a restart
Pipes — used for inter-process communication with child processes (e.g., executable dictionaries, format schema compilers)
Threading — ClickHouse spawns thread pools for query execution, merges, mutations, fetches, and background tasks
Thread synchronization — futex is the foundation for all mutexes, condition variables, and read-write locks in ClickHouse
Thread scheduling — ClickHouse adjusts thread priorities for background merges vs. interactive queries
Thread-local storage and robust futexes — required by glibc/pthread for thread management internals
Signal handling — ClickHouse installs handlers for SIGTERM (graceful shutdown), SIGINT, and fault signals for stack traces
Process/thread identity — ClickHouse checks uid/gid for permission handling and logs thread IDs in traces
Credential changes — ClickHouse drops privileges from root to clickhouse user on startup inside Docker
Time — ClickHouse reads wall clock and monotonic clock for query profiling, timeouts, and event timestamps
Resource limits — ClickHouse checks and sets file descriptor limits and memory lock limits at startup
System information — ClickHouse reads CPU count, memory size, and hostname for distributed query routing and logging
Name resolution — ClickHouse resolves hostnames for ZooKeeper/Keeper, remote() table function, and replication endpoints
Process lifecycle — ClickHouse calls exit on clean shutdown and exit_group for thread-safe termination
Memory locking — ClickHouse can mlock pages for the mark cache and index cache to prevent swapping critical data
Filesystem mount namespace — needed by Docker entrypoint scripts to set up volumes and tmpfs mounts
Extended attributes — ClickHouse may read xattrs for SELinux labels or capability metadata on data files
Miscellaneous — umask for file creation permissions, personality for uname compat check, seccomp for nested filtering
Perf and profiling — ClickHouse supports hardware-counter-based query profiling via perf_event_open
Memory policy — ClickHouse can use NUMA-aware memory allocation for better performance on multi-socket servers
DISABLED: io_uring — modern async I/O subsystem. Has had multiple kernel CVEs (CVE-2021-41073, CVE-2022-29582, CVE-2023-2598, etc.)
DISABLED: mount/umount — ClickHouse has no need to mount or unmount filesystems; volumes are mounted by the container runtime
DISABLED: ptrace — process tracing is not needed and would allow inspecting other container processes
DISABLED: time modification — ClickHouse must not alter the system clock; NTP should handle time synchronization on the host
DISABLED: personality with UNAME26 — the UNAME26 flag fakes kernel version strings and is abused for sandbox escapes
DISABLED: modify_ldt — modifying the Local Descriptor Table is a historic privilege escalation vector on x86
DISABLED: POSIX message queues — ClickHouse does not use POSIX MQs; blocking them reduces IPC attack surface
DISABLED: fanotify_mark — filesystem-wide notification marks require CAP_SYS_ADMIN and are not needed by ClickHouse
DISABLED: process_mrelease — releasing another process's memory is a privileged operation with no ClickHouse use case
DISABLED: kexec/reboot/swap — ClickHouse must never reboot the host, load a new kernel, or manage swap; these are host-level operations
DISABLED: kernel modules — loading or unloading kernel modules from a container is a critical security boundary violation
DISABLED: kernel keyring — ClickHouse does not use the kernel key management facility; secrets are managed externally
DISABLED: BPF — eBPF program loading from a container is a privilege escalation risk with no ClickHouse requirement
DISABLED: userfaultfd — user-space page fault handling has been used in kernel exploits and is not needed by ClickHouse
DISABLED: kernel accounting and quota — ClickHouse does not manage process accounting or disk quotas at the kernel level
DISABLED: namespace creation — ClickHouse should not create new namespaces; the container runtime manages namespace isolation
